from those next several verses of Scripture what we find happens is the focus of Scripture now shifts from the life of Abraham to the life of Isaac and we find that this happened remember as we studied back in Genesis chapter 11 for just a moment turn back there if you will and I want you to just notice what God is giving us in chapters really chapters 10 and 11 of the book of Genesis you begin to read of these genealogies and all of the the sons of Japheth and the sons of Ham and the sons of Shem and you read of all of these descendants and then we find at the end of chapter number 11 that the Bible gives us all the descendants of Shem, and it begins to provide us with all of these names and all of these years and all that's taken place, and we find that we come to this place where the Bible tells us in verse number 26 of Genesis 11, and Terah lived 70 years and begat Abram, Nahor, and Haran, and we find that it's at that point that the Bible begins to focus its attention on Abram, on Abraham. We find even as we studied and looked throughout the text of Scripture, beginning in those messages at that particular place in the book of Genesis, how that the Hebrew race and the promise that God had given with regard to the Lord Jesus Christ and the line, the messianic line, and all of the prophecies of Scripture, and we find how that the broadness of the scope of Genesis 10 and Genesis 11 of understanding the genealogies and all of these descendants and so on, and it just zeroes in on Abraham, and we read all of these chapters and all of these events of a hundred years of the life of Abraham. Remember it was that God said this as we read Galatians, and just hold your place, yeah, just turn over to Galatians, you don't need to hold your place in Genesis anymore, but go over to Galatians, if you will, and I want you to know what God tells us here in the book of Galatians in chapter number 3, and we find again how the the attention of Scripture, the focus of Scripture from Abraham now shifting to Isaac, and we see this in Galatians 3 and verse number 16. Notice what the Bible says, "...now to Abraham and his seed were the promises made." Notice what it says, "...he saith not unto seeds, plural, as of many, but as of one, and to thy seed, which is Christ." We've mentioned in the past the phraseology of the title of a book that was written by William Scroggie, the unfolding drama of redemption, and we find how God, no doubt He could have given us all of the history of any of the other descendants that He chose to give us because He knows everything, but in His plan, in His plan of redemption, the Messianic line, the birth of Christ, we find that the shift of Scripture, the focus now shifts from that of Abraham to Isaac specifically. Just a few verses given to us with regard to the descendants of Ishmael and the death of Ishmael, and then you begin to read about Isaac, you begin to read about his life, and then you begin to read about his sons, and you begin to read about Israel as a nation and the twelve tribes, the twelve sons, and you see the focus. And Matthew 1 says this, and we'll close with this text of Scripture as we think about the truth that God has given us with regard to the shift of Scripture and understanding that Isaac is the distinct heir. We find that the Bible tells us this in Matthew 1. Matthew 1, beginning in verse number 1, the book of the generation of Jesus Christ, the son of David, the son of Abraham. Abraham begat Isaac. Is that what it says in verse number 2? And Isaac begat Jacob, and Jacob begat Judas and his brethren. We're not gonna go down through all of the text of Scripture here, but we find that focus of Scripture. Why? Because it's showing us that messianic line in which Jesus Christ would come to this earth, God in flesh. We find that it's in verse number 16, it says, "...and Jacob begat Joseph, the husband of Mary, of whom was born Jesus, who is called Christ." So all the generations from Abraham to David are 14 generations, and from David until the carrying away into Babylon are 14 generations, and from the carrying away into Babylon unto Christ are 14 generations. I'm so thankful that God has given us a record, the Word of God, the pure Word of God. He's given us a record of these descendants and how He's promised the birth of Christ, and through the pages of Scripture we can trace and route and understand what God is doing and how God is working. This evening, as we look at this portion of Scripture, we think about the death of Abraham, I'll just close with saying this, we can rejoice in the testimony of a life well lived. We can rejoice. Listen, it's a blessing to be able to go. I went to a funeral not long ago, and you know, when you attend a funeral service, there are times in which there's, it's a home-going service, I mean, it's a wonderful rejoicing time of knowing that the individual walked with God and served God, and they're now with God, and what joy. And I had the privilege of attending such a funeral not long ago, and it was just a sweet service, a testimony of a faithful follower of Jesus Christ. That's my desire. A pastor friend that was there, it was for Pastor Mike Reed's wife, and Mrs. Reed, we prayed for her for a long time, Mrs. Reed went home to be with the Lord, and man, it was a wonderful, wonderful service. And a pastor friend that was sitting next to me at that funeral, he tapped me on the arm at the end, he said, this is what all of us should desire in a funeral service, a celebration of a life that was lived for Christ. And as we think about Abraham, and we think about the life of Abraham, we ought to rejoice in a life lived for the Lord, a life in which he followed the Lord. He went out not knowing where he went, just following the Lord. And he saw God do some amazing things. Was he perfect? No, not by far. Can we find critique? Can we find criticism? Can we poke at and say, look at this failure, and look at that? Absolutely. There's flaws. He's a man. But we find that he's the friend of God. He's in Hebrews 11. He had great faith. We say, man, I desire that when I die, I don't know when it's gonna be, could be tonight, probably you're not gonna live to 175. But whatever the time is, that I would decide that I want to follow the Lord, all in, all for him, because I want to have a life that's well lived. Let's pray together. Father, we love you. We thank you for loving us. We thank you for the life of Abraham. And as we look at this portion of Scripture, we're encouraged. But I would admit this evening that in addition to being encouraged, we are challenged in our own lives. And I pray that we'd take a few moments by way of invitation tonight to evaluate our own lives, to consider our own mortality. I trust that each one that's gathered here this evening knows you as their personal Lord and Savior. But if there might be one that's not sure of heaven, it'd be our prayer that tonight they'd be saved. With the thought that primarily we're speaking to believers this evening, I pray that we would be purposed in our lives. That we'd find that it was not by accident that Paul was able to say that he finished his course. For he set out and declared this purpose in Acts 20, that I might finish my course with joy. And God, I pray that for each one of us this evening, we know not how much longer we have in this race. We know not when our course will end. It is my prayer that each of us would have a desire to finish our course with joy. That we'd seek to walk with you and obey you. That we'd be doers of the Word. That your favor would be upon us, because we walk in obedience. We pray that you'd move and work as only you can. We'll thank you for every decision that's made, for it's in Christ's name we pray.

segments.text: of this evening, the book of Genesis, the 25th chapter, Genesis chapter number 25 this evening.
And we have had the opportunity now for some time to be studying through the book of Genesis.
And it's been a great encouragement to me. I trust to you as well. And this is lesson number 59
through the book of Genesis. I won't tell you when we started, but it's been a while and we will
eventually. So there's 50 chapters. So we're halfway. Amen. Isn't that awesome? And praise
the Lord. And Genesis 25, we'll be looking at verses 1 through 11 this evening. And of course,
we were first introduced to Abram back at the end of Genesis chapter number 11. It was in the 12th
chapter in the first part of the chapter that we read about the call that God placed on the life
of Abram and his response to that call of departing from the Ur of the Chaldees. And he
went to a place whether he knew not. And we find that as we've traced the steps of Abram, Abraham
became his name in Genesis chapter number 17. We've had the privilege from the end of chapter
number 11 all the way through the first part of here, chapter 25 this evening, to really trace
the steps of a hundred years of this man's life. Isn't that exciting? And as you study the life
of Abraham, of course, his name is very familiar to us and to many around the world. He is one of
the patriarchs. He is one that often was referenced as you would study through the gospels. And
you look at his course testimony throughout the word of God. And this evening, as we come to this
chapter where his death and burial are recorded, I trust it'll be a great encouragement to each of
us as we consider really a life well lived. A life in which, yes, had ebbs and flows, had
mountain peaks and valleys, had disappointments and great victories. And you think about the
way in which we can relate to a life like that because we too live in this flesh and we live
in this fallen world. And there are days in which we deal with adversity and great opposition and
disappointment. But we find that our God is always faithful and he is always trustworthy and dependable.
He always does what he says he will do. And as we look at the life of Abraham tonight, as we look
at this portion, I trust that you'd be encouraged. Look at verse number nine with me. We'll get right
into the message. The Bible says this in verse number nine, and his sons, Isaac and Ishmael,
buried him in the cave of Machpelah in the field of Ephraim, the son of Zohar the Hittite, which is
before Mamre. I've just titled the message this evening from that phrase in verse number nine,
Isaac and Ishmael buried Abraham. As we look at the portion of scripture, if you're taking notes
this evening, what you notice first of all, the descendants of Abraham. We begin reading this
portion of scripture and we find that as you enter down into and get familiar with the timeline,
you find that Abraham, when he dies, is 175 years old. And so therefore, we would find that this
particular text of scripture that is given to us takes place 38 years after the death of Sarah.
Now, of course, we read and studied the portion of scripture a few weeks ago in Genesis 23,
where the Bible told us of the death and burial of Sarah and how that Abraham came to mourn for
Sarah and to weep for her. And we find that at that time he was 137 years old, and now we find
that he's 175 years old. And so these 38 years have now passed, and the Bible begins by telling
us in verse number one of the text of scripture, then again, Abraham took a wife and her name
was Ketorah. We find that as we read the next few verses of scripture that we'll read of the sons
that were born to Abraham through Ketorah. But before we look at that, as we think about the
descendants of Abraham, of course, we'd first have to go back to Genesis chapter number 16
and see the birth of Ishmael. We find that he, of course, was the one that was born really after the
flesh, Hagar being the the mother of Ishmael. We understand the disappointment that was contained
within the portion of scriptures we studied many months ago and had the opportunity to see how that
through the counsel of Sarah and all that had taken place. And Ishmael is born, and we find
that it was after the flesh. This was not the son of promise, as we'll find. That, of course,
was Isaac. And we find that in chapter number 21, the Bible tells us that God gave the instruction
to Abraham to cast out Ishmael along with Hagar. We find that as we study that portion of scripture
and coupled it with the book of Galatians that Paul references under the inspiration of the Holy
Spirit of God that this is an allegory. And the reality is that the son of the flesh cannot dwell
with the son of promise. We think about the truth of being redeemed, and we think about the old nature
and the new nature, and we understand that the old nature must be mortified. It must be crucified.
We must walk in the spirit so that we do not fulfill the lust of the flesh. And what great
truth is given to us there. We find that as they were cast out according to Genesis 21, verses 20
and 21, that he, Ishmael, dwelt in the wilderness of Paran. We also find that the Bible tells us
that his mother, Hagar, took him a wife out of Egypt. Now, we understand that that would be
understood. Not only the scriptures tell us that, but she, of course, Hagar, was from Egypt, and so
it would make sense that she would return to find a wife for her son from Egypt. We then read about
Isaac, the birth of Isaac. It's given to us in Genesis 21, and as we would look at and refer to
the birth of Ishmael as being after the flesh, we would find this birth of Isaac. He is the son of
promise. We find that the Bible tells us in Genesis 21, in verse number one,
and the Lord visited Sarah as he had said, and the Lord did unto Sarah as he had spoken.
For Sarah conceived and bare Abraham a son in his old age at the set time of which God had spoken
to him, and Abraham called the name of his son that was born unto him, whom Sarah bare to him,
Isaac. Now, God had given many promises to Abraham over the years with regard to this son that would
be born, but, of course, Abraham and Sarah to have a son and the covenant that would be established,
and we find the fulfillment of that birth there in Genesis 21. We find here in our text of
Scripture, well, last week in Genesis 24, we read about the wife of Isaac, Rebekah. We looked at the
entirety of chapter 24, and we find in verse number five, the Bible says of Isaac, of Genesis 25,
that Abraham gave all that he had unto Isaac. We now read of these sons of Keturah. It tells us
that Abraham took a wife. Her name was Keturah. Notice in verses two and three, the Bible tells
us, and she bare him Zimran, and Jokshan, and Midan, and Midian, and Ishbak, and Shuah, and
Jokshan begat Sheba, and Dedan, and the sons of Dedan were Asheram, and Latusham, and Lamumim,
and the sons of Midian, Ephah, and Epher, and Hanok, and Abida, and Eldah. All these were the
children of Keturah. And so you read of the sons, Zimran, Jokshan, Midan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah,
and then the grandsons that are mentioned there, the descendants of these particular sons that are
listed for us as well. But we find that in this list, of course, many Arab nations would come from
these sons that were born. We find that the name that is most familiar out of this list of
names that is provided to us of these sons of Keturah would be that of Midian. Of course,
as you look at Bible history and you read through the Scriptures, you will read many things with
regard to the Midianites. And as you read about the Midianites and you read about some of the
adversity between the descendants of Midian, the Midianites, and the people of God, the nation of
Israel, you will see that there was some real hostility between the descendants of Midian and
the descendants of Isaac. And we see that throughout the pages of Scripture. And so
Midian is absolutely the most familiar, biblically speaking, that we see. But these particular sons
of Abraham would be where many Arab nations would, of course, come from. And we read of those
things historically. It tells us that Abraham gave all that he had unto Isaac in verse number five.
We see in verse number six, it says this, but unto the sons of the concubines which Abraham had,
Abraham gave gifts and sent them away from Isaac, his son, while he yet lived eastward unto
the east country. And so we notice in verse number six, of course, in verse number five, it tells us
that Abraham gave all that he had unto Isaac. There were some gifts that were given to these
sons that are mentioned in verses two and three, and to these sons were given gifts. But I want you
to notice that the Bible says that Abraham sent them away from Isaac, his son, and where did he
send them? Eastward unto the east country. And again, as you would think about the Arab nations
that would descend from these individuals, you would find
that in that region of the world there would be able to trace their lineage, etc., and so we find
that the place of where they were sent by Abraham is noted for us. And we see the descendants of
Abraham, and we know that as we continue through the scripture, I want you to really look at
verses 7 through 10, number 2 if you're taking notes, the death of Abraham. As we look at the
death of Abraham, I am encouraged, it's just a couple of verses of scripture, but I believe that
it's encouraging when you think about the opportunity to walk with the Lord and to live
a life that is well-pleasing. Notice what the Bible says in verses 7 and 8. The Bible says this,
and these are the days of the years of Abraham's life which he lived, and hundred, threescore,
and fifteen years. Then Abraham gave up the ghost and died in a good old age, an old man,
and full of years, and was gathered to his people. When you think about someone that dies,
you understand that there are preparations that are made, even in our culture and our custom,
with having funeral services, etc. And if I were to look at verses 7 and 8 this evening,
I would look at those as really being a eulogy. And you think about the eulogy that would be
given, and obviously the length of eulogy here is quite short, but we find that God gives us
some very interesting things with regard to the life of Abraham. We find that he is 175 years
old, according to verse number 7, and we find that he walked with the Lord for a hundred years.
That's a lengthy period of time. You think about that, if you go all the way back to Genesis 12,
as I mentioned by way of introduction, that God calls Abram, and he calls him from the Ur of the
Chaldees, and over the next 100 years from that initial response, that call that God gave to
Abram in Genesis chapter number 12, all that we've read in all of these chapters, and watching
Abraham grow and develop, and thinking about the increase of his faith, and how God was
revealing himself to Abraham, and how wonderful that is. We begin to reflect on our own lives,
and we think about the journey that we're on, and we understand that no one's having a funeral
service this evening, but we begin to think about when was it that we started walking with God,
and however many days God would give us the length of our life, and to consider the opportunity that
we have to walk with him. It's interesting, I was just praying yesterday about the importance of
finishing well, and finishing strong, and understanding that it's good to start out
strong, it's good to start out well, but to finish well, to hear as Paul, as it's recorded for us in
2 Timothy chapter 4, to think about a life where he's finished his course. Not only did he finish,
but he kept the faith. And, you know, you can finish, but did you finish with the same beliefs
that you started with? Did you finish serving the Lord as faithfully as you started? And we find that
as we look at the life of Abraham, and we consider these 100 years of walking with God,
and you consider the mountaintops, and the valleys, and you consider great victories, you consider
the way in which God had revealed himself to Abraham, the names by which God gave to Abraham,
and describing the character, the very nature of God, and how he revealed himself to Abraham.
What a blessing! And, you know, we began as we looked and saw that God revealed himself as
El Elyon, and you think about God being the possessor of heaven and earth, and the impact
that that made upon Abraham. And then, of course, when he told him that his name was El Shaddai,
and you think about the truth that he is the Almighty God. Abraham was wavering at times, and
wondering as to the promise that God had given with regard to a descendant. We know that there
were times that he said, what about this, that's the servant that's born in my house? And God says,
no, that's not the way it's going to work. I'm going to give you a son, and Abraham,
you and Sarah will have a son. And you think about the way in which God was proving Abraham,
and the way in which God was showing us, even through the account of Scripture, the plan that
God has, and the ways in which we just walk with him and trust him, and find that he is always
faithful. It was in Genesis chapter 22 that we had the opportunity to read about the great test
that Abraham faced when God says, take thine son, thine only son, and go up to the mount that I'll
show thee of. And it was there that he was to offer Isaac as an offering. We find that it was
in that text of Scripture that we really find a mountain peak of faith in the life of Abraham,
where he believed that God would provide. And as we read the book of Hebrews in the 11th chapter,
we find that it's revealed to us there that Abraham understood that even if he had to kill
his son, that God was able to raise him up. And what faith! We mentioned this as we studied that
portion of Scripture a few weeks ago, and even as we've looked at the miracles of the Lord Jesus
Christ during our Sunday School series, and we've considered the fact that Abraham, at that
particular time, there's no one in recorded biblical history that had been raised from the dead,
but Abraham believed that God was able. What faith! And we read about all of these events,
and we read of the record that God has given us of these hundred years, and we can rejoice,
and we can thank God for the testimony of this man Abraham. We find that it's in verse number eight
that the Bible describes it this way, and these are the days of, excuse me, verse number eight,
that Abraham gave up the ghost and died. Notice what it says, in a good old age, an old man. 175,
I guess that is pretty old, and he died an old man. And it says this, and full of years,
and was gathered to his people. It's interesting that phrase, full of years, the word full,
it literally means abounding or satisfied. And oftentimes when we read it as full of years,
we may think about it as really the quantity, but really, when we look at the text of Scripture,
we find that verse number seven and part of verse number eight deals with the quantity of life,
that he was 175 years old, that he was an old man, and we find the quantity of life,
but really, in that phrase in verse number eight, when it says, and full of years,
really what's being focused upon is the quality of life. Not only the quantity, but the quality.
To think about the satisfaction, to think about the abounding nature of Abraham's life. Remember,
it was back in Genesis 24, in verse number one, when the Bible tells us that Abraham was old and
well stricken in age, and the Lord had blessed Abraham in all things. What a great testimony.
The Lord had blessed Abraham in all things. God blesses, or the blessings of God, we think,
and we mention, and we thank God for his blessings, and we are encouraged through song to
count your blessings, name them one by one. I mentioned last week how that the reality is that
there are times in which our understanding or definition or description of a blessing may differ
from what God would look at as being a blessing. There are times when God says no, and I would
submit to you this evening that that's a blessing. We say, no, I want God to say yes. Sometimes God
says no, and that's a blessing, and we need to thank God for it, and we think about the trials
and difficulties and how God is growing us and developing us, and we find the blessings that God
had bestowed upon Abraham. As we look at the Word of God, I want you to consider this truth that
Moses gives us in Deuteronomy. Turn to the 11th chapter, if you will. We'll be back to Genesis
here in just a moment, but I want you to think about this when the Bible tells us that God blessed
him, and we understand the content of what God is telling us, and really the summary of the life of
Abraham, and to think about the blessing of God upon him that the Lord had blessed Abraham in all
things, and we find that in Deuteronomy chapter 11, and this is a biblical principle that we find
throughout the Word of God. I want you to notice, begin looking with me in verse number 26 of
Deuteronomy 11. The Bible says this, "'Behold, I set before you this day a blessing and a curse.'"
That sounds like a pretty good deal. There's a blessing and a curse, and so I want the blessing,
right? If we took and pretended this evening, used our sanctified imaginations to say
that there were two lines and a header over the door where the line would be formed, and
the description of that particular door, one says, "'Blessing, enter here,' and the other says,
"'Cursing, enter here.'" You'd be crazy to get in the line that said, "'Cursing.'" Right? Somebody
thinks something's wrong with you. You say, but this line is shorter. There's a reason it's
shorter, amen? And you get in the line that says, "'Blessing.'" You say, yeah, that's what I'm
signing up for. I desire God's blessing upon my life. Do you desire the blessing of God upon your
life? Sure you do. The favor of God, the blessing of God, knowing that all that
God gives us is for our good and for his glory, amen? And we say, God, I want your
blessing, I want your favor upon my life. But as we know that as Moses is giving
this instruction to the children of Israel, and he's saying to them as
they're preparing for entering into the land of promise, he says this in verse
27, a blessing if you obey the commandments of the Lord your God which
I command you this day. So we'd find that blessing is directly tied to obedience,
correct? A blessing if ye obey the commandments of the Lord your God which
I command you this day. He says today, listen, behold, I set before you this day
a blessing and a curse. A blessing, but it's tied directly to obedience. Notice
in verse 28, and a curse if ye will not obey the commandments of the Lord your
God, but turn aside out of the way which I command you this day to go after other
gods which you have not known. As you study the history of Israel through the
Old Testament, you'll find there are many times in which they obeyed God. They had
the favor of God, they had the blessing of God. You find, however, that with much
frequency you read that the nation of Israel disobeyed the commandments of the
Lord, correct? Often, as you read the accounts throughout the Word of God of
the disobedience of the people of God to the commandments of God, it was not the
fact that the commandments were not known to the people of God, it was not
that they were not given the truth, it was that they chose to disobey. It was
that they rebelled against what God said and we find that there would be cursing,
there would be judgment, there would be opposition and adversity, and we find
that they would deal with great troubles and trials and various levels of
opposition. We find eventually, of course, as you note, the nation of Israel as a
whole, and you think about the divided kingdom and, of course, the ten tribes of
the north being taken captive by the Assyrians, and years later, Judah, the
tribes in the south, being taken captive by the Babylonians. Why? Because of their
disobedience. When Jeremiah is prophesying to the nation of Judah on
the eve of the Babylonian captivity, he's seeking to encourage them to trust the
Lord and we find that God is revealing to Jeremiah and Jeremiah sees the
Babylonians have laid siege against the city and he understands the the days are
coming in which they'll be taken captive and there are people, the king
and others, that would come and say, is there a word from the Lord? The word's
not changed, you've disobeyed and judgment is coming. Will God fight for us?
And Jeremiah says, actually God will fight against you. Wow, what tragic news
received that God Almighty would fight against them, but it was because of their
disobedience. And so when we see the life of Abraham and we see the eulogy that is
provided and we think of the quantity of life, but we also think of the the
quality of life, that he was full of years, that he was both abounding and
satisfied, the reality that he had walked with God and that he had seen and
experienced the blessing of God and that God had blessed him in all things, and we
understand this evening that the blessing of God is tied to obedience.
It's a biblical truth all throughout the pages of Scripture and how vital it
is that we make that decision that we would obey the Lord, follow his word, I
will obey, and what a place to be. We find that it's in James chapter
number 2 and the the New Testament truth that is given to us here, what a
powerful verse of Scripture where the Bible says that the Scripture was
fulfilled which saith Abraham believed God and it was imputed unto him for
righteousness and he was called the friend of God. In James 2 and verse
number 23, Abraham was called the friend of God. I'm thankful for the life of
Abraham and as we think about the eulogy and we think about and even reflect
upon our own lives, you'll recall that in Genesis chapter 23 as we looked at the
life of Sarah and the death and the burial of Sarah that we mentioned that
we're told by Solomon that it's better that we would go to the house of mourning
than to the house of feasting, and we understand that the reason that it's
better, that it's more advantageous for us to go to the house of mourning
than to the house of feasting is because that is the end of all men. Man goes to
his long home. And as we think about the life of Abraham and we look at just a
couple of verses of Scripture but really consider in very brief overview fashion
the the hundred years that are summarized in these chapters in the
book of Genesis where God allows us to have insight to the life and experiences
of Abraham, I wonder this evening how it is that at the time of our death what
will the eulogy sound like? What is it that that someone would say of us when
they look at our life? Would they look at our life as being a testimony of a life
that that was lived for the Lord? A life, a testimony of a believer that trusted
the Lord, that followed the Lord, that had faith? Oh not anyone that's perfect for
we know that none of us are perfect. But we've come to the place where we've
yielded and we've surrendered and we have sought to walk with God and we've
desired and longed for that blessing of God upon our lives. We find that Abraham
had a wonderful testimony. We find not only as you would think about a death
and a funeral, you think of the eulogy but you also think of the burial and we
find it in verses 9 and 10 God gives us the record of the burial of Abraham. The
Bible says that his sons Isaac and Ishmael buried him and so we find that in
the beginning of verse number 9 that the people that are involved are revealed to
us and we find here that the Bible tells us that Isaac and Ishmael buried him in
the cave of Machpelah. Now it's interesting that Isaac and Ishmael are
now referenced in this portion of scripture. We find that of course at this
particular time when you do all of the calculations in determining the death of
Abraham and his age being a hundred and seventy-five years old that Isaac at
this time is 75 and Ishmael is 89. Now if you go back to the 21st chapter of the
book of Genesis that's where we read of the birth of Isaac and you'll remember
that as we went through the portion of scripture that we come down and you find
that in verse number 8 of Genesis 21 the Bible says the child grew speaking
of Isaac and was weaned and Abraham made a great feast the same day that Isaac
was weaned and Sarah saw the son of Hagar that's Ishmael the Egyptian which
she had born unto Abraham mocking and it was at that time in which Sarah said
